bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 25, 1946

div1.p: Hench informs Kean that he has decided not to publish a preliminary memorial volume, and that he is unable to finish a full study anytime soon. He hopes to acquire a few important missing items concerning the yellow fever episode.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, June 25, 1946
div1.opener:
June 25, 1946
General J. R. Kean
2804 N Street, N. W.
Georgetown
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for sending me the corrected answers. I believe
that I have the uncorrected copy to all of them, but only your corrected
answers to the last part, however, I have already received a lot to follow
up from these questions and answers when I see General Truby this next
Sunday, June 30. I cannot tell you how much I appreciate the wonderful
help you gave me in Washington. I am afraid I took a great amount of your
time and I fear I must have tired you. What a wonderful collection of items
you found and gave to me. There will be invaluable and I cannot thank you
enough.

We are leaving this Thursday for San Francisco and after a week there
will spend four or five days resting at Santa Barbara, where I hope to see
Huston Lazear. Perhaps it won't be a rest after all, but I badly need one.
I am giving two talks at the American Medical Association and have been
working busily on them for the last forty-eight hours.

Your letter of June 19, in which you frankly expressed your opinion
that it would not be wise for me to publish a preliminary memorial volume,
has really relieved me a great deal. Frankly, I have never been very anxious
to do that and have been worried lest the publication detract materially from
the full work. I more or less evolved the idea for a preliminary memorial
volume chiefly to satisfy my very real sense of obligation to those of you
who have helped me so much. I wish indeed that I could promise to finish
my full volume in the next couple of years, but I fear that this is impossible
because of the pressure of my daily work and the urgent need for me to get
along with my, to me important and promising, research.

I keep plugging away on the Yellow Fever story whenever I can on free
evenings and week-ends, but there is still some unfinished business and
there are still a few important missing items, in addition, of course, to the
missing Lazear-Reed data which John Carroll has and which I still hope to get.
I believe that the Fiftieth Anniversary could be memorialized by an appropriate
article which would take only a fraction of the work that the publication of
a memorial volume would. I am very, grateful for your frank opinion about this.
Permit me to discuss it with General Truby and Doctor Hewitt, head of the
editorial staff of the Mayo Clinic, and you will hear from me further about this.

I had a pleasant interruption this week. Into my office walked
Mr. Gust Lambert. I was snowed under with consultations, therefore I put
him up for the night at a hotel and interviewed him for three or four hours
the next morning with the help of a secretary. Frankly, he told me a few
things that it is difficult for me to believe. I believe I have mentioned
one or two of them before. When his interview is typed up, I will send you
a copy for your perusal and comments.

Please see the enclosed letter to my friend, Dr. Darrell Crain.
Because I am leaving, I do not want his reply to me to be held up; therefore,
I am asking him to telephone you direct. I am sure he will help you out.
I only wish I know enough about Washington clinics and hospitals to give
you the information directly. I was very glad indeed to help your cook
and perhaps I can help her further on my next visit in the fall.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:lcg
